Well that didn't work! :smile_cat:  Looks like Travis is still working on 3.7 support. So I guess I'll just close this for the time being.

Locally, I'm seeing quite a few failures. A good potion of those seem to be due to the use of `async` as a kwarg as it is now a now reserved keyword. https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html

@andrewsomething Thanks!

Things to do:

* Travis: use dist: xenial and sudo: required to get Python 3.7 support, see https://github.com/python-trio/trio/pull/556 for an example.
* Delete the async variable in the Azure compute driver 
* Stop raising StopIteration
* Stop assuming that urlquote("~abc") will give '%7Eabc': it [gives '~abc' on Python 3.7](https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.parse.html#urllib.parse.quote).

The full list of backward-incompatible changes: https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html#porting-to-python-37

Thanks for the great work! I'm toying with it now. I notice that the API docs list `location=` as arg for a location, but you've coded `region=`.

Is that a misunderstanding on my part?

The variable names used in Python don't have to match the parameter names sent to the API... I tried to be as consistent with other drivers as I could, though some naming was already in place before I got involved.

I'm not sure I'm following; 
http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/latest/compute/api.html says to use `location=`, so as an avid RTFM'er I would expect that.

However, I had to use e.g.
```python
cloud = get_driver(Provider.SCALEWAY)(access_key, token)
cloud.list_images(region='ams1')
```
which tripped me over ;)

Right. Because Libcloud is a library for several cloud providers, it has several established conventions for certain concepts, such as using `region` as the name for that argument where most drivers need it. Its name in the Python code doesn't have to be the same name passed to the API endpoint on Scaleway's end, so it isn't. All the Scaleway folks are documenting is how to talk to their servers; the Libcloud adapter has its own documentation for its own conventions.

hi @micafer this is great! I'm going to find some time soon to carefully look at this and test this against an OpenStack Pike (and perhaps also Ocata) environment.

I don't know if setting your own API version is actually a good idea?  The idea is that the driver code is written against a known API version.  If you tell Azure to use a different API version, the driver code may be out of sync if the Azure API has a different expectation or response than what the driver code was written for.  What's your use case?

@tetron My main concern was using a single API version for all the calls. But, I also found that I was not able to tag a network interface in the 'West US 2' region with the older version.

That said, I agree that the driver wouldn't expect a different response, but shouldn't the driver at least use the same API version instead of using different versions for multiple calls?

And if not, I am open to suggestions to get around this without letting users specify the version.

Here's part of my stacktrace that was the reason behind me letting users specify the version:
